message.content:
Sure! Here's a Python script that uses Plotly to plot the "value" as a function of "date", split by "category" in different subplots:

```python
import plotly.graph_objects as go
from plotly.subplots import make_subplots
import pandas as pd

# Read the input data from file
df = pd.read_csv("input_data/input_data.csv")

# Create a subplot figure
fig = make_subplots(rows=len(df["category"].unique()), cols=1, shared_xaxes=True)

# Loop through each category and plot the data
for i, category in enumerate(df["category"].unique(), 1):
    category_data = df[df["category"] == category]
    fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(x=category_data["date"], y=category_data["value"], mode="lines", name=category), row=i, col=1)

# Set x-axis and y-axis titles
fig.update_xaxes(title_text="Date", row=len(df["category"].unique()), col=1)
fig.update_yaxes(title_text="Value", row=int(len(df["category"].unique()) / 2), col=1)

# Set the layout of the figure
fig.update_layout(
    title="Value as a function of Date",
    template="simple_white"
)

# Export the figure as a JSON file
fig.write_json("output_charts/value_vs_date.json")
```

Make sure to place your input data file `"input_data.csv"` in the correct folder `"input_data/"`. The output JSON file will be saved in the `"output_charts/"` folder with the name `"value_vs_date.json"`.
